comments.body:
Nice :+1:
If trying to edit a type not supported by this module, `class_name_to_type()` will return None and will not give clear error message?
Similarly if creating new and omitted type, will it give clear error message?

> will it give clear error message?

yes, we will send it to the API, but the error returned is clear and to the point.

> If trying to edit a type not supported by this module, class_name_to_type() will return None and will not give clear error message?

provider['type'] can only be `supported_providers().keys()` so it should not be `None`, but even if it is ^^ :-)
`class_name_to_type()` has fallthrough return None if it doesn't find (unless I'm reading it wrong)

p.s. added checks for null or bad provider type, checked ... this can happen if we manually tweak the type in the DB, and then send an edit request without explicit type :-)
[EDIT: no this can not happen, but leaving the test, it may help in some other case ... ]

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +512,516 @@        # if we do not have a provider_type, use the current provider_type
        if provider and not provider_type:
            provider_type = manageiq_provider.class_name_to_type(provider['type'])

        # check supported_providers types

comments.body:
:+1: this works around https://github.com/ManageIQ/manageiq/pull/13400 bug, and possibly helps with older API versions that had less fields (as long playbook doesn't specify the new fields).

Subtle: here you omit top-level None fields, in create only inside endpoints.
Does this allow you to do partial edit?

comments.body:
it get a little out of hand here :-)

can you re-factor this functions to use a dict instead of a long list of args ?
@yaacov I can have a go but as you can probably tell I'm no python expert. @cben mentioned he had an idea to refactor this so I was just continuing to add providers... :)

the easiest way I can think of:

define some function
```
def some_func(provider_info):
    post(provider_info["name"], provider_info['ems_id'])
    ...
```
call some function
```
provider_info = dict(name = "hello", ems_id = "world")
some_func(provider_info)
```
@cben sounds legit to you ?
@snecklifter ^^
if pep is ok with it ... LGTM as is

comments.body:
You're still sending this to API as uid_ems, this means this PR is not dependant on the API PRs to allow `azure_tentant_id`, right?

That's cool, I just want to understand the plan for ansible X manageiq compatibility.
1. will uid_ems always work or will module *have* to send `azure_tenant_id` later?
2. how long has manageiq already supported `uid_ems` for this?  any stable releases?
  I.e. if module later switches to sending `azure_tenant_id` will it break older manageiq and will it need to try both?
3. This module already accepted `uid_ems` param ‚Äî for just a few days since #34708 ‚Äî is it OK to remove it now?
  "Feels OK" to me but @yaacov @elad661 do you know what are the ansible rules for this?
  (I know, I reviewed #34708, sorry didn't read the comments then)

Personally, I'm cool with dropping `uid_ems` baggage completely, but that might depend on (2) and (3).

regarding question number 3, I think it's okay to remove it - this has only been merged for 3 days, and wasn't in any released version of ansible (afaik), so it's unlikely that anyone is relying on it anyway.
